div1.p: [Carter] discusses the breeding of mosquitoes in palm leaves.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Victor G. Heiser, February 10, 1925
div1.opener:
Copy for Dr. Beeuwkes.
/LC
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
February 10, 1925.
Dear Doctor Heiser:
div1.p: Your letter of February 9th., just received.

My recollection is that I said that the breeding places of
Stegomyia were in collections of water in artificial containers
or things that simulate them and this would include holes in rocks:
knotrat-holes and axile of leaves, I think.

What I was skeptical about--and rather more than “a trifle
skeptical”--was that they bred in mud holes when their normal
breeding places, as above given, were available.

I have read Haworth's article. The same breeding in palm
trees: “cocked hat trees” (Dracaenia) and similar trees and shrubs
has been reported by men from West Africa and especially by Bacot
(a most careful epidemiologist). We also found them in Colocassia
in Panama, though not “of sanitary importance.”

Stegomyia aegypti were not found so as to be of sanitary im-
portance in West Africa in cocoanut palms. I am inclined to think
that in the hedges of Dracaenia much in Sierra Leone they may be. With other Stegomyia,
naturally, we have, so far, no concern.

The yellow fever vector is not likely to breed in places exposed
to full light or wind. Connor and some others have reported their
general absence in the high unshaded cisterns: on the roofs and
scaffolds in Central America and Mexico and, as I recall, in Guaya-
quil. This may be the explanation to their rarity in cocoanut and
other palm trees.

I should rather suspect the travelers palm as capable of pro-
ducing them so as to be of sanitary importance than any other. It
is rarely tall: its leaf axils contain a considerable amount of
water (not much under 1/2 a pint) which is deep enough in them to be
well shaded and dark.

Some, possibly considerable, investigation of the biology of
this vector will probably have to be made in West Africa before
the work of control can be planned to the best advantage. Did I
tell you that, induced by the paper I gave you, Stevens wrote me
that MacFie had been sent to West Africa to “check up” on the Ste-
gomyia breeding there? I have, too, a letter from Gordon (R. Mount)
of the Sir Alfred Lewis Jones Research Laboratories, Sierra Leone,
stating that he is sending me reprints of some articles on Stegomyia,
“which may have escaped” my “notice.” If there is anything new in
them I will send them to the I. H. B. Gordon, as you know, was
the man who made the experiments to determine the preferential time of
feeding of Stegomyia (day or night) at Manaos--in 1921, I think.

I very greatly enjoyed seeing you and hope you never fail to
call in when you are in Washington.
With very best remembrances from Laura and myself,
